data: PED NIA Discomfort and Malaise Associated with Fever
Refer to Decision Support Tool: Fever: Treatment for Discomfort and Malaise
Fever in patients below 60 days of age: follow guideline and prescribers orders for "Fever in the Infant Less than 60 Days of Age"
Use axillary route for measuring temperature in neonates to avoid rectal perforation
For temperature 38.0 C or higher (any route)
Not applicable if:   - Oncology patient  - Patient has potential surgical problem  - Patient does not have signs of moderate to severe dehydration (10% or greater)
Patient must be 3 months of age or older for acetaminophen administration
No history of acetaminophen administration in last 4 hours
When child’s temperature is 38.0 C or greater, may give both acetaminophen and ibuprofen together or at the nurse’s discretion. If only giving one, ibuprofen is preferred if safe to give.
15 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: oral liq, first dose: NOW
15 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
20 mg/kg, rectal, once, drug form: supp, first dose: NOW
Patient must be 6 months of age or older for ibuprofen administration
No history of ibuprofen administration in last 6 hours
Ibuprofen may be administered as a second option one hour after acetaminophen when a child's temperature is 38.5 C or greater
No history of other NSAID administration in the last 8-12 hours (e.g. ibuprofen)
10 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: oral liq, first dose: NOW
10 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
Notify provider to obtain ongoing orders for discomfort and malaise associated with fever
